content: The "Fairness in Autism Treatment Act of 2007" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 of the Act introduces amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, specifically addressing parity for pervasive developmental disorders. The "Fairness in Autism Treatment Act of 2007" introduces amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, requiring group health plans to provide coverage for pervasive developmental disorders, including therapeutic care for individuals under 22 years of age, both in-network and out-of-network. The "Fairness in Autism Treatment Act of 2007" mandates group health plans to cover pervasive developmental disorders for individuals under 22 years old, both in-network and out-of-network. Plans cannot impose annual or lifetime dollar limits on these benefits unless they apply to all medical and surgical benefits. The "Fairness in Autism Treatment Act of 2007" requires group health plans to cover pervasive developmental disorders without imposing high deductibles or cost-sharing. Additionally, plans cannot deny eligibility for enrollment or renewal based on these disorders. The requirements of this section must be treated as a material modification in the plan, with notice provided within 60 days of the first plan year. Small employer exemptions are also outlined. Small employer exemptions are outlined based on the number of employees. Employers must adhere to rules similar to those in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to determine if they are considered a single employer. For new employers, the determination of being a small employer is based on the expected average number of employees in the current year. Predecessors are also taken into account. The term 'predecessors' is included in the definition of an employer. An exemption from increased costs applies if the application of the section results in a cost increase of at least 1 percent for a group health plan. The term 'pervasive developmental disorder' is defined as a developmental disability. Preemption and relation to state laws are also addressed. The section discusses preemption and relation to state laws regarding health insurance coverage. It clarifies that state laws are not preempted if they meet the requirements of the section. Conforming amendments are made to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. The table of contents in the Act is amended to include a new item after section 713, numbered 714. Sec. 714 introduces parity for pervasive developmental disorders, effective for plan years starting on or after January 1, 2009. This amendment is part of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically under section 9813. Sec. 714 introduces coverage for pervasive developmental disorders in group health plans, including therapeutic, respite, and rehabilitative care for individuals under 22 years old. It specifies requirements for in-network and out-of-network benefits for these disorders. Group health plans must provide coverage for pervasive developmental disorders without imposing annual or lifetime dollar limitations specific to these disorders. Additionally, cost-sharing for these disorders cannot exceed that of medical and surgical benefits under the plan. Eligibility to enroll or renew coverage under the plan cannot be denied solely to avoid the requirements of this section. Small employer group health plans are exempt from these requirements. The term 'pervasive developmental disorder' is defined as any developmental disability, and small employer group health plans are exempt from providing coverage for these disorders if it results in a cost increase of at least 1 percent.
